articles.headline: President Seeks to Rally Support for Syria Strike
articles.snippet: The Obama administration began a full-press campaign for Congressional approval of its plan to carry out a punitive strike against the Syrian government.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration began a full-press campaign for Congressional approval of its plan to carry out a punitive strike against the Syrian government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration began a full-press campaign on Sunday for Congressional approval of its plan to carry out a punitive strike against the Syrian government.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Disruptions: More Connected, Yet More Alone
articles.snippet: A YouTube video about pervasive smartphone use may have landed at a moment when people start questioning if something has gone too far and start doing something about it.
articles.abstract: A YouTube video about pervasive smartphone use may have landed at a moment when people start questioning if something has gone too far and start doing something about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last weekend, I was watching television with a few friends, browsing the week’s most popular YouTube videos, when a piece in the comedy section called “I Forgot My Phone” caught my eye. As I was about to click play, however, a friend warned, “Oh, don’t watch that. I saw it yesterday, and it’s really sad.”

articles.headline: Verizon Nears Deal to Buy Out Vodafone’s Stake in Wireless Unit
articles.snippet: Verizon Communications neared a deal on Sunday to buy the 45 percent stake in its wireless business held by Vodafone of Britain for about $130 billion, people briefed on the matter said, potentially completing a corporate breakup over a decade in ...
articles.abstract: Verizon Communications neared a deal on Sunday to buy the 45 percent stake in its wireless business held by Vodafone of Britain for about $130 billion, people briefed on the matter said, potentially completing a corporate breakup over a decade in the making.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:35 p.m. | Verizon Communications neared a long-anticipated deal on Sunday to buy the 45 percent stake in its wireless business held by Vodafone of Britain for about $130 billion, heralding a continued sweeping realignment within the global telecommunications landscape.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Mark Scott

articles.headline: News Corp.’s Tight Grip on Australia’s Papers Shapes Its Politics
articles.snippet: The company owns roughly 60 percent of the newspaper market share and recent outlandish front pages depicting political leaders have some saying it holds too much political sway.
articles.abstract: The company owns roughly 60 percent of the newspaper market share and recent outlandish front pages depicting political leaders have some saying it holds too much political sway.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A lot has happened since Col Allan, the editor in chief of The New York Post, returned to Sydney to provide “extra editorial leadership” for Rupert Murdoch’s Australian newspapers.

articles.headline: Huge Summer for Hollywood, but With Few Blockbusters
articles.snippet: Ticket revenue in North America totaled $4.71 billion, up 10.2 percent from last summer, but a competition glut hurt films that could have been hits in a thinner field.
articles.abstract: Ticket revenue in North America totaled $4.71 billion, up 10.2 percent from last summer, but a competition glut hurt films that could have been hits in a thinner field.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Here in Hollywood, the land of false-front movie sets and business-has-never-been-better studio spin doctors, summer ticket sales are being summed up with a single word: blockbuster.

articles.headline: Fast and Flawed Inspections of Factories Abroad
articles.snippet: While some audits are performed in depth, retailers often choose “check the box” inspections that fail to uncover substandard conditions and outright fraud.
articles.abstract: While some audits are performed in depth, retailers often choose “check the box” inspections that fail to uncover substandard conditions and outright fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inspectors came and went from a Walmart-certified factory in Guangdong Province in China, approving its production of more than $2 million in specialty items that would land on Walmart’s shelves in time for Christmas.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: History Aside, Obama Bets on Congress
articles.snippet: By asking Congress for authorization to retaliate against Syria, President Obama has put himself at the mercy of an institution that has bedeviled his presidency for years.
articles.abstract: By asking Congress for authorization to retaliate against Syria, President Obama has put himself at the mercy of an institution that has bedeviled his presidency for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In President Obama’s telling, Congress plays host to an “endless parade of distractions and political posturing.” It is the “challenging” place where his second-term agenda meets Washington gridlock, forcing him to issue executive orders and make appeals to the public to get anything done.

articles.headline: Campaign Journalism in the Age of Twitter
articles.snippet: A far younger campaign reporter now feeds a never-ending news cycle named Twitter.
articles.abstract: A far younger campaign reporter now feeds a never-ending news cycle named Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Timothy Crouse’s seminal campaign book, “The Boys on the Bus,” the crusty political reporters settle on the story that they will tell the world at the end of the day.

articles.headline: Drug Agents Use Vast Phone Trove, Eclipsing N.S.A.’s
articles.snippet: The scale and longevity of a data storage program run by the government in partnership with AT&T was unmatched by other government programs, including the National Security Agency’s gathering of phone call logs.
articles.abstract: The scale and longevity of a data storage program run by the government in partnership with AT&T was unmatched by other government programs, including the National Security Agency’s gathering of phone call logs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For at least six years, law enforcement officials working on a counternarcotics program have had routine access, using subpoenas, to an enormous AT&T database that contains the records of decades of Americans’ phone calls — parallel to but covering a far longer time than the National Security Agency’s hotly disputed collection of phone call logs.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Colin Moynihan

articles.headline: Rubber-Suit Monsters Fade. Tiny Tokyos Relax.
articles.snippet: In an era when digital effects have made the use of small models and suited actors look quaint, tokusatsu, or “special filming,” is on the way out.
articles.abstract: In an era when digital effects have made the use of small models and suited actors look quaint, tokusatsu, or “special filming,” is on the way out.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHOFU, Japan — Daisuke Terai plays one of the best-known characters in the history of science fiction, but few fans have ever seen the actor’s face. That is because Mr. Terai puts on a bright silver and red rubber suit before stepping onto a set made of miniature trees and buildings to do battle as the cosmic superhero Ultraman.
